system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

Dear [Patient's Name],

I am writing to provide a comprehensive summary of your recent hospital stay, which commenced on March 10, 2024, due to a fall and subsequent loss of consciousness. Throughout your admission, you were under the meticulous care of our medical staff until your anticipated discharge on March 20, 2024.

Upon admission, you experienced diminished consciousness with a recorded Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 11. Initial evaluations noted slurred speech which prompted immediate investigations. A computed tomography (CT) scan performed on March 11, 2024, confirmed the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke located in the right hemisphere of your brain.

Laboratory tests conducted on March 11, 2024, revealed a slightly low hemoglobin level with an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count. Moreover, your coagulation profile indicated an elevated International Normalized Ratio (INR), suggesting a prolonged bleeding time.

In response to the intracerebral hemorrhage and associated cerebral edema, you were commenced on Mannitol at a dose of 0.25 g/kg administered every six hours. Additionally, antihypertensive medications were initiated to manage your blood pressure, administered as dictated by your blood pressure readings.

Despite these interventions, your clinical course was marked by neurological challenges, including right-sided weakness and persistent slurred speech. The GCS remained at 11 with episodes of agitation and confusion noted, necessitating ongoing safety measures to mitigate the risk of further falls.

On March 12, 2024, during discussions with your family, it was emphasized that your condition remained critical with the necessity for continued close monitoring and care. The goal remained to stabilize your condition to facilitate eventual discharge once deemed safe.

As you transition from hospital to home care, it remains imperative to maintain follow-up appointments with your primary care provider and neurologist to assess your recovery and adjust your treatment plan as needed. Continuous monitoring of your neurological status and blood pressure, along with adherence to the prescribed medication regimen, will be crucial to your ongoing recovery.

Please contact your healthcare provider promptly should you experience any sudden changes in your health, such as worsening of neurological symptoms or new concerns.

We are committed to your recovery and encourage you to reach out should you require further information or assistance. Thank you for entrusting us with your care during this challenging time.

With best regards,

Dr. ___
